{{italictitle}} '''Trespass''' '''''vi et armis''''' was a kind of lawsuit at [[common law]] called a [[tort]]. The cause of action alleged a trespass upon person or property ''vi et armis'', [[Latin]] for "by force and arms." The plaintiff would allege in a [[plea]]ding that the act committing the offense was "immediately injurious to another's property, and therefore necessarily accompanied by some degree of force; and by special action ''on the case'', where the act is in itself indifferent and the injury only consequential, and therefore arising without any breach of the peace."<ref>Lord [[William Blackstone]], ''[[Commentaries on the Laws of England]]'', Vol. 3 p. 153.[https://books.google.com/books?id=2UcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA153#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> Thus it was "immaterial whether the injury was committed willfully or not."<ref>''Taylor v. Rainbow'', 2 Hen & M. 423</ref>
In ''Taylor v. Rainbow'', the defendant negligently discharged a firearm in a public place and caused the loss of the plaintiff's leg. The defendant was held to be liable for medical bills as well as lost earnings as a result of the disability.<ref>''ibid.''</ref> Thus, proof that the act or omission was unintended was no defense to an action of trespass ''vi et armis'' and the liable party would pay for all consequent damages.
Recovery for damages for a trespass ''vi et armis'' were limited only to the direct consequences of the act or omission causing the injury. For instance, the state of [[West Virginia]] reported that monetary loss for detention from business as an indirect result of the injury were not recoverable under an action for trespass ''vi et armis'', but were available under the related action of [[trespass on the case]], also known as an action ''ex delicto'' "against the wrong."<ref>Barnum v. B. & O. Railroad Co., 5 W. Va. 10</ref>
Trespass ''vi et armis'' was a precursor to many other forms of lawsuits at common law. The cause came to be formulaic and in many cases fictitious. For instance, a lawsuit against a defendant had spoiled wine with salt water required an allegation that he had done so with bows and arrows.<ref>See e.g. ''Rattlesdene v. Grunestone'' (1317).</ref> The ancient courts at common law developed trespass upon the case as an alternative pleading to causes of action which arose neither from force nor weapons. In modern times, the specific formalities of the distinction between the two have dropped in favor of [[notice pleading]] or code pleading and actions for [[negligence]], [[Battery (tort)|battery]], [[trespass to chattels]], and [[conversion (law)|conversion]].
The related phrase of '''''contra pacem regis''''', "against [[Queen's peace|the King's peace]]", was necessarily not a required element of trespass ''vi et armis'' although it was possible for both allegations to appear in a lawsuit when the intentional use of force or weapons breached the peace.

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Yasser Al-Habib | image = | imagesize = 200px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1979|1|20}} | birth_place = [[Kuwait]] | residence = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | religion = [[Shia Islam]] (Twelver) | website = http://al-qatrah.net }}
'''Sheikh Yasser al-Habib''' (Arabic: ياسر الحبيب born 20 January 1979) is a [[Muslim]] [[Shia]] cleric, the founder and the head of the London-based Khoddam Al-Mahdi Organization, as well as Al-Muhassin mosque in [[Fulmer|Fulmer, Buckinghamshire]]. Al-Habib attempts to express his religious views and his investigations and conclusions in the Islamic history, based upon Shia and allegedly Sunni sources.
Al-Habib started his religious activities in Kuwait, starting off as a member of the Dawah Party, later he founded a non-profit religious organization named Khoddam Al-Mahdi Organization, and he also expressed his religious views regarding [[Abu Bakr]] and [[Umar]], and criticized them sharply, which led to anger the mainstream [[Sunnis]] in Kuwait and other Arabic-speaking Sunni communities, and finally led to the arrest of Al-Habib. Later, in February 2004 he was released under an annual pardon announced by the [[Amir]] of Kuwait on the occasion of the country's [[National Day#Kuwait|National Day]], but his rearrest was ordered a few days later. Al-Habib fled Kuwait before he was sentenced [[trial in absentia|''in absentia'']] to 10 years' imprisonment,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/annualreport.php?id=ar&yr=2005&c=KWT |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2004 - Kuwait |publisher=Amnestyusa.org |date= |accessdate=27 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218151217/http://www.amnestyusa.org/annualreport.php?id=ar&yr=2005&c=KWT |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> and spent months in Iraq and Iran before gaining an asylum in [[United Kingdom]] which is his current place of residence.
== Early life == Al-Habib was interviewed by [[Elaph]], a well-known Arabic online newspaper, where he stated that he was born in a religious Kuwaiti family, and started his education in the Kuwaiti governmental schools, before joining [[Kuwait University]] and graduating from its Political sciences faculty. Besides his secular studies, Al-Habib stated that he studied the traditional Islamic under the guidance of his teacher [[Mohammed Reza Shirazi|Ayatollah Mohammed Reza Shirazi]].<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.elaph.com/Web/news/2010/11/614420.html |script-title=ar:ياسر الحبيب: هذه قصة خروجي من السجن.. والمستقبل للتشيع |publisher=Elaph |date= |accessdate=2 February 2014|language=ar}}</ref>
In 2011, he founded Khoddam Al-Mahdi Organization at [[Kuwait]] and In 2003, Al-Habib was sentenced to 35 years in prison in Kuwait for insulting Aisha and Sunni caliphs, who are revered in [[Sunni Islam]]. However, his imprisonment was cut short in 2004 on the occasion of the country's [[National Day#Kuwait|National Day]], but his rearrest was ordered a few days later. He fled the country first to Iraq, then to Iran. Then he went to London where Seyed [[Mojtaba Hosseini Shirazi]], younger brother of [[Sadiq Hussaini Shirazi|Sadiq Shirazi]], has lived for forty years. Finally he could get asylum in Britain.<ref name="vice">{{cite web | url=http://www.vice.com/en_uk/read/meet-the-controversial-shia-cleric-bringing-sectarian-tension-to-the-uk | title=Meet the Controversial Cleric Threatening to Turn UK Muslims Against Each Other | date=10 May 2013 | accessdate=25 February 2015 | author=Omar Shahid and Tamanna Ali}}</ref>
Now he lives in [[Fulmer |Fulmer, Buckinghamshire]], and had started his religious and political activity such as founding Al Muhassin Mosque and setting up [[Fadak (TV channel)]].<ref name="independent">{{cite web | url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/sunni-vs-shia-in-gerrards-cross-new-mosque-highlights-growing-tensions-among-british-muslims-8671969.html | title=Sunni vs Shia... in Gerrard's Cross: New mosque highlights growing tensions among British Muslims | publisher=The independent | date=24 June 2011 | author=Milmo Chahal}}</ref>
==Views== He recorded two lectures in English titled: ''Who killed the Prophet Muhammad'' and ''Why do Shiites hate [[Umar]] Ibn al-Khattab''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alqatrah.net/en/video-y/index.php?catb=5&part=1 |title=The drop, Office of Sheikh Al-Habib in London - Video Youtube |publisher=Alqatrah.net |date= |accessdate=27 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917085608/http://alqatrah.net/en/video-y/index.php?catb=5&part=1 |archivedate=17 September 2010 |df= }}</ref> Sunni Al-Sha'ab newspaper described Sheikh al-Habib as a traitor and [[apostate]] in its main page, at the time that Al-Habib cursed [[Abu Bakr]] and [[Umar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alqatrah.net/edara/index.php?id=143 |title=القطرة - موقع رؤى ومحاضرات الشيخ الحبيب - الطائفة البكرية تفتح النار على الشيخ الحبيب بالأكاذيب والافتراءات في وسائل الإعلام |publisher=Alqatrah.net |date= |accessdate=27 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917072346/http://alqatrah.net/edara/index.php?id=143 |archivedate=17 September 2010 |df= }}</ref>
=== Wahhabism === Al-Habib said: {{cquote|Wahhabism is a criminal and violent ideology, founded by a mentally ill man named Muhammad Ibn Abdul-Wahhab about three centuries ago. Its main principle is that all Muslims who perform [[Tawassul ]] and visit their graves are regarded as apostates and infidels. Therefore, the seizure of their life, property and women would, like that of the infidels, be religiously lawful and permissible!<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-drop.net/en/question/index.php?id=42 |title=The drop, Office of Sheikh Al-Habib in London - Answers - What do Wahhabis believe in |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724094102/http://www.the-drop.net/en/question/index.php?id=42 |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>}}
=== Views on Sunnis === Sheikh al-Habib refers to Sunnis as [[Bakriyyah|Bakris]], meaning the followers of Abu Bakr. He says that the real Sunnis (''Ahlul Sunnah'') are the ones who follow the [[Sunnah]] of Muhammad, that is Shia Muslims. He continues that Sunnis today follow the Sunnah and teachings of Abu Bakr instead, having rejected [[Ali|Ali ibn Abi Talib]] and [[Ahlulbayt]]. He explains in one of his lectures titled ''Bakris think they are Sunnis, but in reality are not'' that when people wanted to distance themselves from the Shia, and follow [[Muawiyah I|Muawiyya]], they started calling themselves the Jama'ah. He explains that the reality behind why people called themselves [[Sunnis|Ahlul Sunnah wal Jama'ah]] only began after the [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] ruler [[Umar bin Abdul Aziz]] forbade the Sunnah (tradition) of cursing [[Ali bin Abi Talib]] publicly (as previously invented by the [[Muawiyah I|Muawiyah]]). It was upon then that people protested to this new prohibition, declaring that [[Umar bin Abdul Aziz]] had prohibited the Sunnah of cursing [[Ali bin Abi Talib]]. Thus they began calling themselves Ahlul Sunnah wal Jama'ah; stressing that they adhere to the Sunnah of cursing [[Ali bin Abi Talib]], and that they are the Jama'ah of [[Muawiyah I|Muawiyah]].
He also refers to those personalities who claim that they belong to [[Shi'a]] but reconcile with the [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] sect as Batris.
He described [[Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah]] (the [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[Marja'|marja]] who died on 4 July 2010)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=2&article_id=116761#ixzz0sr3wTEpL |title=Politics - Tuesday official mourning day for Fadlallah |publisher=The Daily Star |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref> as Batri. Al-Habib said that Fadlallah left a great number of doctrinal deviations, ignorant views and bad conduct which he introduced to the religion of [[Islam]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alqatrah.net/en/edara/index.php?id=102 |title=The drop, Office of Sheikh Al-Habib in London - Sheikh al-Habib Hails our Great Scholars’ Refusal to pay tribute to Fadlullah |publisher=Alqatrah.net |date= |accessdate=27 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917055848/http://alqatrah.net/en/edara/index.php?id=102 |archivedate=17 September 2010 |df= }}</ref>
== Celebrating Aisha's death anniversary and its reaction == In September 2010 Sheikh Yasser al-Habib angered the [[Sunni]] Muslims by calling [[Aisha]], "an enemy of God" which led Kuwait to revoke his citizenship accusing him of trying to stir up discord among Muslims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cde302c6-c732-11df-aeb1-00144feab49a.html |title=Financial Times|publisher=ft.com |date= |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFLDE68M0QD20100923 |title=Reuters|publisher=reuters.com |date= |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wtopnews.com/?sid=2057568&nid=105 |title=Federal News Radio|publisher=wtop.com |date= |accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref><ref> [http://www.newser.com/article/d9ibqf600/kuwait-strips-hard-line-shiite-activist-of-citizenship-after-claims-of-blasphemy.html Kuwait strips hard-line Shiite activist of citizenship after claims of blasphemy - 9-20-2010 12737 PM Newser]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kuwaitsamachar.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=51891:revoking-al-habibs-citizenship-premature-safar&catid=150:kuwait-times&Itemid=471|title=Revoking Al-Habib's citizenship premature Safar KuwaitSamachar|website=www.kuwaitsamachar.com}}{{deadlink|date=June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://iplextra.indiatimes.com/article/0cUh8ga7F7d9X?q=Kuwait |title=Kuwait strips Shiite activist of citizenship |publisher= |accessdate=11 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713025737/http://iplextra.indiatimes.com/article/0cUh8ga7F7d9X?q=Kuwait |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In October 2010 [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Iranian Supreme Leader]] [[Ali Khamenei]] tried to calm tensions between Shias and Sunnis by issuing a [[fatwa]] against insulting Muhammad's companions and wives.<ref name="Islam Times"/> {{quote|Cursing the wives of the prophets and the wives of the Great Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is one of the taboos and prohibitions.<ref name="Islam Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.islamtimes.org/en/doc/article/39715/fatwa-closes-the-doors-in-front-of-any-sedition-between-sunnis-and-shiites | title=Fatwa closes the doors in front of any sedition between the Sunnis and the Shiites | publisher=Islam Times | date=9 October 2010}}</ref>}}
== Criticism == After Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei issued the fatwa outlawing the insult of Sunni Dignitaries (Aisha, Abu Bakr and Umar ibn al-Khattāb),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/Index_view.asp?code=227879 |title=Tehran Times |publisher=tehrantimes.com |date= |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> Al-Habib responded by calling the Islamic Republic of Iran "oppressive". He continued by referring to [[Ali Khamenei|Khamenei]] as "so-called Ali al-Khamenei – who pretends to be a Shia scholar". His reasoning for naming the Iranian government as "oppressive" was because the "regime in Iran today unjustly arrests anyone who celebrates the occasion of Farhat-ul-Zahra and prevents people from visiting the tomb of [[Pirouz Nahavandi|Abu Lulu]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alqatrah.org/en/edara/index.php?id=123 |title=The drop, Office of Sheikh Al-Habib in London - Sheikh al-Habib takes an oath to 'publicly' voice opposition to the enemies of Ahlul Bayt and warns al-Khamenei |publisher=Alqatrah.net |date= |accessdate=24 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025093456/http://alqatrah.org/en/edara/index.php?id=123 |archivedate=25 October 2010 |df= }}</ref>
Senior Iranian cleric [[Naser Makarem Shirazi]] has referred to Al-Habib as a "hired agent or a mad man" <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alqatrah.net/en/edara/index.php?id=122 |title=The drop, Office of Sheikh Al-Habib in London - Sheikh al-Habib remarks on Naser Makarem Shirazi's statement |publisher=Alqatrah.net |date= |accessdate=18 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025213853/http://alqatrah.net/en/edara/index.php?id=122 |archivedate=25 October 2010 |df= }}</ref> and stated: "Recently an illiterate fool non clergy U.K citizen in the name of Shia has insulted sacred matters of Sunni Muslim brothers".<ref name=" ABNA">{{cite web | url=http://www.abna24.com/english/cultural/archive/2010/10/05/207567/story.html | title=Grand Shia Cleric Calls "Yaser Alhabib" a Fool | publisher=ABNA | date=5 October 2010 | author=Staff writer}}</ref>
Al-Habib has been criticized by several figures and leaders who speak in the name of [[Shiism]] including Ammar Nakshawani, leader of [[Hezbollah]] [[Hassan Nasrallah]], [[Ali Khamenei]] (who also issued a fatwa against cursing of Muhammad's companions) and [[Naser Makarem Shirazi]].
== Response == Sheikh maintains that all he does is teach the Islam as it was and should be, something that was historically disorded by Sunnis and Iran since 1979, especially under the Khamenei.
